Comment: I'm an Australian but come on, the Liberal party has been terrible for decades and Albo is marginally to the left of them.  It'll absolutely be business as usual, and we were screwed no matter which party won.  EDIT: Just to expand on this, this is not the same as Canada. Canadians voted in the same government who'd been screwing them for a decade plus. Ridiculous and pathetic from them.  Here in Australia, we re-elected a government who have only been in power for 3 years. The previous party, had basically been in power for a decade (and also between before 2000 - 2009) and ramped up all things we hate like the housing crisis, mass migration and also destroying any chance of fast internet.  I'm not a fan of Labor (the party who won), but they have not made things drastically worse, they've been about the same as the "right wing" party. That's the problem in Australia, both major parties support corporate interests and our entire economy revolves around keeping house prices high.
Author: Entilen

Comment: We don't have the same gun culture as the US and never did. We had one bad shooting and never did again. It should say something that one of the worst days in Aus history is to the USA, a Tuesday.  But it isn't like the US have ever actually risen up against your government since the Civil War.  I have nothing to base this thought on other than guy feelings but it's possible that mandatory voting is just as effective at keeping a government in check as an armed populace.  To be clear, I have nothing against the US in their honour of the 2nd amendment. Gun ownership in the US is something that makes sense to me when it's so engrained in your culture and I think that's actually something to be proud of, so long as it's properly respected of course.  I'm just saying Aus doesn't have a similar culture and as a result, I wouldn't say any movements on the part of the government are a result of our populations access to arms.
Author: TheSearchForMars

Comment: "Liberal" doesn't necessarily mean Left or Progressive. It's become synonymous with those terms in the U.S., but I personally think it's a gross oversimplification. Separately it would be weird for a country that's technically a monarchy to call the conservative party "republican."

Comment: I mean, sure, the people always get what they deserve, but Trump did reverse the polls. It is funny to imagine Canadians endorsing the current trajectory because they unironically thought Trump was going to send the US military into Ottawa or something.  Truthfully, until Canadians are fed up with their healthcare/welfare system the whole country is doomed to stagnate. Their GDP/capita from 2011 is 97% the size of what it currently is. Americans have been going ballistic about 20% real median income growth over the last 15 years not being enough, but Canada's almost assuredly has been negative. Of course immigration isn't helping, but their immigration rate had been consistent from 2000 up until around the pandemic (where it doubled) and the stagnation predated it by a decade.
